trails.name: Abrams Falls Trail
trails.description: A popular moderate hike that leads to a pretty 20-foot waterfall. Located in Cades Cove.

trails.name: Albright Grove Loop Trail
trails.description: This loop trail through an old growth forest is located off of the Maddron Bald Trail. Use the Maddron Bald trailhead to access.

trails.name: Alum Cave Hike
trails.description: This very popular hike takes you up to Alum Cave which isn't really a cave, but a rock overhang. One can continue on up to Mt. Leconte from this trail.

trails.name: Andrews Bald Hike
trails.description: This a relatively short, though moderate hike to Andrews Bald. Access from the Clingmons Dome parking area. This is a crowded area, but the moderate difficulty of the hike means less crowds on this trail.

trails.name: Avent Cabin Hike
trails.description: Park at the Jakes Creek Trailhead in the Elkmont area of the park. This is a relatively short hike to an old historical cabin structure. The Elkmont area was a popular vacation resort prior to the area becoming a national park. Photo by Brian Stansberry, Wikimedia Commons.

trails.name: Balsam High Top Hike
trails.description: A strenuous hike that follows the Benton MacKaye Trail as it climbs up Balsam Mountain. There are no views at the top, so do this hike for the exercise and the solitude.

trails.name: Baskins Creek Falls Hike
trails.description: A hike close to Gatlinburg where you can view waterfall, take a short side trip to a cemetery, and see some views of nearby ridges and Gatlinburg. Tip: park on Cherokee Orchard Road before the beginning of the one-way Roaring Fork Motor trail. Take a short walk up the road to find the trailhead. When you leave you can make a return trip on Cherokee Orchard Road and avoid the typical slow, heavy traffic Roaring Fork Motor Trail

trails.name: Bullhead Trail to William's Pulpit
trails.description: This involves hiking the Bullhead trail. Start this hike from the Rainbow Falls trailhead parking lot. This trail was closed for a few years due to the wildfire that struck the area in late 2016. This trail can be used to reach the top of Mt. Leconte but this particular hike is most famous for reaching 'The Pulpit', a large rock cairn built by the CCC in the 1930s.

trails.name: Charlie's Bunion Hike
trails.description: This is a classic hike on the Appalachian Trail to a very scenic rock outcropping with a wonderful view. You can combine this hike with the Jump Off for a 10+ mile day in the park. There is a good amount of climbing experienced on this hike so it is generally considered to be a strenuous hike. Trail leaves from the Newfound Gap parking lot.

trails.name: Chasteen Creek Cascade Hike
trails.description: This is an easy hike from the Smokemont area of the park. This is a good hike for wildflowers and opportunities to play in the creek. The namesake of the hike is a 30-foot high waterfall cascade. You will use the Bradley Fork Trail to reach the Chasteen Creek Trail.

trails.name: Chimney Tops Trail
trails.description: One of the park's most iconic trails, the Chimney Top trail is a must do for anyone visiting the park and who is up for more than an easy hike. Unfortunately, a devastating wildfire struck the park in late 2017 and it's origin was the Chimney Tops. The trail was closed for a number of years as result and only recently opened to what it is today. You can no longer hike to the top of the Chimney Tops, but instead you hike up to a newly created observation point.

trails.name: Deep Creek Loop
trails.description: This is a popular moderate hike from the North Carolina side of the park. You'll follow Deep Creek and visit a number of waterfalls along the way. This trail is noted for being one of the first tails constructed by the CCC in the park.

trails.name: Grotto Falls
trails.description: This is a very popular waterfall hike and because of it's relatively easy nature, it's a must-do for many people visiting Gatlinburg and the park. Parking can be very difficult, so get there early. The hike not only takes you to the nameksake waterfall, but you also get to walk through an old growth forest.

trails.name: Mt. Cammerer Hike
trails.description: This is a very challenging hike up to the top of Mt. Cammerer where you can see a commanding view of the surrounding mountains from an old fire lookout tower. This particular hike uses the Low Gap Trail from the Cosby area of the park. The hike up to the Appalachian Trail is demanding.

trails.name: Laurel Falls Trail
trails.description: The Laurel Falls hike is a classic, easy paved trail to a waterfall. This is a very popular hike, so it will be crowded and parking can be an issue. Best bet is to go as early as you can to find a parking spot and experience the falls with as few people as possible.

trails.name: Mt. Leconte - Rainbow Falls Trail
trails.description: Mt. Leconte is one of the classic destinations in the park and can only be reached by one of several difficult trails. Accessing the top via the Rainbow Falls trail is one of the most popular ways and includes a stop at beautiful Rainbow Falls. This is a tough hike, so be warned. Could also combine this with the Alum Bluff trail and do a through-trip, but be sure to stash a second vehicle at the Alum Bluff trail parking lot or arrange for transportation

trails.name: Mt. Sterling Gap Hike
trails.description: This is the quickest and more moderate way up to the fire tower on top of Mt. Sterling. Enjoy scenic panoramic views from the top. Located in the Big Creek section of the park which isn't nearly as crowded as the main section of the park

trails.name: Porters Creek Trail
trails.description: A nice option in the Greenbrier section of the park. You will follow Porters Creek for the first part of this hike and also get to explore an old farm site. The John Messer farm is one of a number of historical structures reamining in the park. This is also a great trail for wildflowers in the spring.

trails.name: Ramsey Cascades
trails.description: A beautiful, but difficult, hike up to Ramsey Cascades waterfall. The trail is often rocky and extremely rugged, so be prepared not only for the elevation gain but also uneven footing. Enjoy a relaxing dip in the river before heading back to the car.

trails.name: The Jump Off Hike
trails.description: This hike involves catching the Appalachian Trail from the Newfound Gap parking lot. Most of the hike is along this famous trail until you reach the Jump Off spur trail. At the Jump Off you'll have an amazing view.

hikes.comments: Water levels were high this day so the waterfall was full and flowing fast. Unfortunately the trail was also extremely crowded, but this is one of the most popular trails in the park so go figure.
Brutal hike! The climb up to Low Gap is relentless but the view from the top is amazing!  Great 360 view!!
Great hike up to the pulpit. Great views. Wish we kept going all the way up to Mt. Leconte but that'll be for another day...
Cool hike to find this  cabin once owned by an artist. This is a reminder that people used to live and work in this park before it was a National Park.
Beautiful hike. Not crowded. Took a dip in the river to cool off.
